stream_context.summary: Kaze iterates on a craft-material themed course (crayon/styrofoam mountains, paper/plate mushrooms, desert/pyramid area) while troubleshooting a custom “normal-map-like” lighting trick on N64. He gives a detailed level layout rundown (Luigi crayon escort quest, paper-plane ride star, pyramid red-coin interior, hidden cave entrance, 8‑bit pipe), then pivots planned content by abandoning an ice biome in favor of a castle-themed section due to asset/readability concerns. The stream also touches on constraints from emulator support (F3DEX features) and practical animation limits for 2D doodle characters in a 3D world.
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains a clear course redesign/feature rundown, a major content pivot (ice biome → castle biome), and concrete technical revelations about Kaze’s custom N64 normal-mapping workaround and emulator constraints.

findings.summary: Kaze implemented a custom workaround for N64 normal mapping: the “normal map” is computed on the CPU and rendered as a regular texture by the GPU, but this requires generating a separate texture per surface orientation/rotation.
findings.quote: The N64 does not have normal map support. I added the support. The texture is computed on the CPU, and then the GPU just has to render it. But that means I need to generate one texture for each orientation.

findings.summary: Because the technique is orientation-dependent, assets that aren’t axis-aligned cubes require additional supported rotations; increasing bevel/edge variants can double texture variants (e.g., 4 → 8), raising memory/content cost.

Kaze’s current lighting approach effectively multiplies normal vectors by the camera vector (camera-as-light look), but he wants it to account for the angle between the actual light direction and the camera to preserve “reflective” readability on craft materials like styrofoam.

The stylized “styrofoam mountain” look has unavoidable artifacts with this method: flat/unsmoothed normals, sharp edges, and occasional dark seam lines that can’t be easily softened without increasing geometry or texture variants.

Kaze avoids some advanced rendering paths because emulator support lags behind (he references “F3DEX free stuff” not running on emulators), meaning feature choices are constrained by what common emulators can display correctly.
findings.quote: Emulators are holding us back like that.

findings.summary: He outlines a Luigi quest: the player meets a Luigi doodle who asks for a yellow crayon; the player must pick up/escort the crayon back and “draw the star,” with enemies added to make the escort segment a real challenge.

Course structure update: the red-coin section is moved inside the pyramid interior; other planned stars include a paper-plane ride on a rubber band, a hidden cave entrance star, an 8-bit pipe objective, and a final pure-platforming segment leading to a Toad doodle.

A platforming mechanic is planned around a rolling cylindrical “crayon” (similar to logs you stand on in Mario 64) and a “ruler” trampoline element; Kaze notes the jump onto the rolling crayon must be tuned to be forgiving.
Kaze iterates on replacing low-readability mushrooms with craft-friendly alternatives (paper umbrella / paper plate style). He prefers multitexturing (cheaper) over decals for dotted patterns.

Major pivot: the planned ice/snow section is likely being removed because it’s hard to find convincing craft-material ice assets and performance-friendly snow set-dressing. Kaze decides to re-theme that area into a castle biome instead, leaving the former ice/lava ideas uncertain.
findings.quote: I think I'm changing this to a castle biome. And then snow area is gone. Lava area is also not really a thing anymore.

findings.summary: Enemy/hazard planning shifts: scissors were considered, but Kaze likes “cardboard saw blades” better visually; he also notes potential use of classic Mario 64 enemies re-skinned as cardboard (Thwomp, Bob-omb, Womp) and ideas like falling cardboard bridges that roll back up via a string/spring.
He explicitly wants the world to feel handmade but not “expertly crafted”: doodle NPCs should look amateurish/shoddily drawn rather than polished, to match the craft diorama tone.
findings.quote: We do want this to be a craft level, but we don't want this to be expertly crafted.

biobak.summary: Kaze asks Biobak for feedback on a proposed paper umbrella/plate-style mushroom replacement, indicating Biobak is used as a real-time art direction sounding board during streams.

badub.summary: Kaze reiterates that Badub is producing most of the music; he also implies track-to-level fit is curated (he rejects the idea of Badub making a desert track in that moment).

zeina.summary: Zeina provides (via DMs) doodle/cutout character art (Kaze reviews a Luigi doodle and discusses using doodle NPCs like Yoshi/Toad/Luigi). Kaze then explores how to animate these 2D cutout characters inside the 3D engine.

Animating doodle/cutout characters is constrained by the project’s vertex-weighting limitations (weights are binary: 0 or 1). Kaze experiments with subdividing geometry per “bone” and adjusting weights to allow waving/bending motions without a stick-puppet look.
zeina.quote: It's not that easy, unfortunately, because we only have vertex weights: one or zero.

findings.summary: Lilaa drives multiple readability/art-direction suggestions: replacing mushrooms with paper umbrellas/plates, proposing a Mario Odyssey-style paper grass look, and generally pushing for craft items that read clearly at low resolution through lighting/context.

key_stories.title: Inventing a normal-map look on N64 under rotation and emulator constraints
key_stories.summary: Kaze debates whether his styrofoam surface shading reads correctly and realizes his current approach behaves like camera-driven lighting rather than a proper light+view interaction. He explains that his solution computes a texture on the CPU to mimic normal mapping, but each surface orientation needs its own generated texture, making rounded/complex shapes costly.
key_stories.challenge: Achieve dynamic, readable “reflective” craft-material shading on N64 hardware despite the console lacking native normal maps and despite emulator feature gaps.
key_stories.process: Implemented CPU-side generation of a shading texture; iterated on angle math (camera vector vs. light direction); evaluated geometry/bevel tradeoffs; avoided some modernized microcode/render paths due to emulator compatibility.
key_stories.outcome: A workable but artifact-prone system (flat normals, seams, sharp edges) that influences asset shapes and pushes Kaze toward blockier/more axis-aligned geometry and careful art direction.
key_stories.key_quote: The texture is computed on the CPU... but that means I need to generate one texture for each orientation.

key_stories.title: Course 14 quest and biome reshuffle (ice section removed, castle considered)
key_stories.summary: Kaze gives a full course walkthrough (Luigi crayon escort star, paper-plane ride, pyramid red-coin interior, hidden cave entrance, 8-bit pipe). While planning the final platforming segment, he struggles to make convincing craft-material ice/snow assets and decides to replace the planned ice biome with a castle-themed area instead.
key_stories.challenge: Keep the level dense and varied while ensuring each biome is visually readable as craft materials within N64 limits.
key_stories.process: Repositioned star objectives (red coins into pyramid), planned new hazards and platforming setpieces (rolling crayon/log-like mechanic, rulers, saw blades), then evaluated reference/asset feasibility for ice and pivoted to castle.
key_stories.outcome: Ice/snow content is deprioritized/removed; castle biome becomes the new direction for that segment, with traversal to the paper plane/castle area still unresolved.
key_stories.key_quote: I think I'm changing this to a castle biome. And then snow area is gone.

key_stories.title: Making doodle NPCs feel handmade, then figuring out how to animate them
key_stories.summary: After receiving doodle character art (Luigi/Yoshi), Kaze decides the doodles must look intentionally amateurish to avoid breaking the handmade illusion. He then confronts the technical challenge of animating flat cutout characters using binary vertex weights, experimenting with weight splits and simple wave/bend motions.
key_stories.challenge: Balance the documentary-book-doodle aesthetic with the engine’s limited animation/rigging capabilities.
key_stories.process: Set an art rule (“shitty/amateur doodles”); tested mesh subdivision/weighting to enable waving/bending; compared a flexible cutout approach versus stick-mounted museum-diorama style.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze favors a bending cutout animation style, but needs a repeatable pipeline for clean weighting/subdivision so multiple doodle NPCs can be animated consistently.
key_stories.key_quote: We only have vertex weights: one or zero.

open_questions.context: Kaze says he computes a normal-map-like texture on the CPU and must generate textures per orientation/rotation, which constrains asset shapes and smoothing.
questions: What exactly is the CPU generating each frame (a lit diffuse texture, a lookup, or a precomputed set of variants), and how is it integrated into the SM64 render pipeline?
How many orientations/rotations are supported today for a typical asset, and what memory/time cost does each additional orientation add?
What visual artifacts (seams, flatness, sharp edges) are acceptable, and which ones become blockers for shipping a level?
How do you decide when to change geometry (blockier forms) versus improving the shading math?

open_questions.topic: Emulator compatibility vs. advanced rendering features
open_questions.context: Kaze suggests some “F3DEX free”/newer rendering approaches won’t run properly on emulators yet, limiting what the project can use.
questions: Which specific features (microcode, combiner tricks, display list features) are you avoiding because of emulator limitations?
Do you target specific emulators as minimum spec, or is real hardware the primary target with emulators as secondary?
Have these constraints forced you to redesign any shipped/near-finished assets or levels?

What failsafes will exist for the escort crayon star (respawns, checkpoints, enemy placement) to keep it challenging but not frustrating?
What is the intended route to reach the paper plane and the new castle segment, and what’s the rationale for that traversal choice?

open_questions.topic: Biome pivot: ice/snow removed in favor of castle

questions: What specifically broke the ice concept (performance cost, readability, lack of good craft analogs, or gameplay fit)?
What craft materials will define the castle biome (cardboard bricks, paper-maché, felt banners, popsicle-stick battlements), and how will it visually differ from existing areas?
Does removing ice affect the game’s overall biome variety or the emotional pacing of the course/world?

open_questions.topic: Doodle NPC animation pipeline under binary weights
open_questions.context: Kaze wants cutout doodle characters that can wave/bend, but is limited to vertex weights being 0/1, requiring subdivision per bone and careful weighting.
questions: What toolchain/pipeline will Zeina and Kaze use to produce many doodle NPCs consistently (rig setup, subdivision rules, export constraints)?
What animations are essential (wave, point, talk, react), and how many can be supported without exploding vertex counts?
Will doodle NPCs be purely cosmetic, or will they be tied to quest logic (e.g., Luigi star drawing) with bespoke animations?
